unnormalised: The BSE Sensex did a jig today, closing at a "whopping" 65,500, a whole 25 pts above yesterday's close. Investors, bless their cotton socks, are attributing this monumental leap to... wait for it... positive global cues. As if "global cues" are some magical Bollywood dance number that can fix everything.
normalised: The B-S-E Sensex did a jig today, closing at a "whopping" sixty five thousand five hundred, a whole twenty five points above yesterday's close. Investors, bless their cotton socks, are attributing this monumental leap to... wait for it... positive global cues. As if "global cues" are some magical Bollywood dance number that can fix everything.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, over at the NSE, Nifty50 also joined the party, inching up to 19,400. Brokers are saying "buy! buy! buy!" faster than you can say "chai break." One analyst, Mr. Sharma from Sharma & Sons Investments (motto: "Investing Your Money Since Your Grandfather's Time"), confidently predicted a "bull run" that will last... until lunchtime, probably.
normalised: Meanwhile, over at the N-S-E, Nifty fifty also joined the party, inching up to nineteen thousand four hundred. Brokers are saying "buy! buy! buy!" faster than you can say "chai break." One analyst, Mister Sharma from Sharma and Sons Investments (motto: "Investing Your Money Since Your Grandfather's Time"), confidently predicted a "bull run" that will last... until lunchtime, probably.

unnormalised: Gold, our beloved store of value, also decided to put on its bling, reaching â‚¹60,000 per 10 grams. Seems like even precious metals are trying to keep up with inflation. Banks, those cheeky devils, are still offering a "generous" 6.5% on fixed deposits. That's enough to beat inflation if you don't, you know, actually spend any money.
normalised: Gold, our beloved store of value, also decided to put on its bling, reaching rupee sixty thousand per ten grams. Seems like even precious metals are trying to keep up with inflation. Banks, those cheeky devils, are still offering a "generous" six point five percent on fixed deposits. That's enough to beat inflation if you don't, you know, actually spend any money.

unnormalised: Speaking of spending, retail investors, the true heroes of the stock market, are still pouring money into IPOs. A new company, "Jalebi Technologies," (tagline: "Sweetening Your Portfolio") is all the rage, oversubscribed by a factor of 100x. They promise to revolutionize the way we make jalebis. Or something.
normalised: Speaking of spending, retail investors, the true heroes of the stock market, are still pouring money into I-P-Os. A new company, "Jalebi Technologies," (tagline: "Sweetening Your Portfolio") is all the rage, oversubscribed by a factor of one hundred times. They promise to revolutionize the way we make jalebis. Or something.

unnormalised: So there you have it, folks. Another day, another sideways shuffle in the stock market. Remember, investing is like a spicy plate of biryani. A little bit of profit, a little bit of loss, and a whole lot of indigestion. Consult your financial advisor, unless they're currently busy buying jalebi stock. Then, godspeed!
normalised: So there you have it, folks. Another day, another sideways shuffle in the stock market. Remember, investing is like a spicy plate of biryani.
